data.text: Simple Food Options for Bikepacking
Hey everyone, just wondering what everyone likes to take bikepacking for meals? Looking for simple ideas besides dehydrated meals.

I like long grain rice, kidney beans or red beans & spicy/hot sausage. Takes a minute to finish the rice but worth it. Filling & good energy & protein. Also granola, trail mix (a lot of nuts) & dried fruits(papaya, pineapple, apple, banana)
data.author: Joshua Ceci

data.text: I like the flavored tuna that comes in the envelopes paired with a tortilla. You can sometimes find them on sale for pretty cheap. Hard boiled eggs can stay good for a few days if you leave them in the shell. I watched an Adventure Cycling video on YouTube where they discussed food options and they had a lot of great ideas. You should search for it.
data.author: Steve Cardin

data.text: , absolutely hard boiled eggs. & package tuna & dried fish,I forgot those! & crackers, I like triscuits.
data.author: Joshua Ceci

data.text: Break up a box into thirds of Stovetop stuffing and a pouch of chicken breast. Very tasty.
data.author: Fred Vaughn

data.text: Tuna fish and cous cous. Cold soak and no stove is required. Oatmeal for breakfast.
data.author: Patrick Taylor

data.text: I dry my own meals using ingredients I like, but I try to use fresh ingredients the first few days out, & snacks like roasted nuts & dry salami.
data.author: Cheryl Leskiw

data.text: Mac & cheese with bacon and onions.
data.author: Patrick J. Kane

data.text: Flour tortillas are handy for a trip. You can add peanut butter and jelly or add pouch of Spam.
data.author: Fred Vaughn

data.text: I always start off with 1-2 salamis and a handful of baby else. Oranges and apples hold up well too. I love these gluten free bread crackers. I like to blend a meat with cream cheese and out in a refillable suitable container. I eat that up day 1-2. Smoked salmon. For dried meals i usually go mountain house (i hate all the preservatives) and i add a ton of dried kale that i dehydrated from the garden. Chicken and rice is hands down my fave.
data.author: Rebecka Weinsteiger

data.text: Smoked salmon is going for $29/pound at my local grocery store, in Allegan, Michigan. Ouch ! ‚Ä¶ (correction: that‚Äôs the price for smoked salmon jerky. Regular smoked salmon is only $22/lb. Tuna comes from thousands of miles away, and is so cheap ! How can that be ? )
data.author: Rian Mintek

data.text: Muesli dried cereal with some Niddo whole dried milk makes a good hot breakfast. I mix the cereal and milk powder in single serve ziplock bags.

data.text: Boil in the bag rice along with bagged curry lentil or similar sauce . Heat/cook in boiling water and no mess in stove! (Bowls are obviously)

data.text: I usually will grab a few packs of cheese crackers and a bag or stick of pepperoni‚Ä¶ like mini pizzas‚Ä¶ my kids love them. More of a snack / but ü§∑‚Äç‚ôÇÔ∏è
data.author: Jeremy Bechthold

data.text: I like the granola, apples, bagels (Dave‚Äôs Killer or others that are good raw), hard boiled eggs, ‚Ä¶suggestions especially for later days in multi day trip. A couple favorites that I prep in advance Split Red lentils, potato, carrot and onion all hold up well and mix with curry powder. Red lentils only require a short time to cook and mix in with the saut√©ed veggies for protein. It‚Äôs so much more flavorful than any dehydrated meal I‚Äôve had plus can be done in one pot. Saut√© all then add water to desired consistency and give lentils 5-10 minutes (note whole lentils require 15-20, split < 10). Premix whole rolled oats (steel cut require too much time IMHO and instant are best used as wallpaper paste) and muesli with vanilla, cinnamon, pumpkin spice and sugar if you like. Can cook with just water, powder milk, or I carry a couple single serve milks that don‚Äôt need refrigerated til opened. You can bring to boil then let sit in pan while breaking camp and ready to eat. Much better than packaged. I usually add an apple to it and nuts if you don‚Äôt use muesli or know lunch is going to be a while. Yes, it weighs a bit more but really not much as the only extra weight is the water in carrot, onion and potato plus 1-2 cup of milk or about 1 pound.
data.author: Jim Lee

data.text: Ramen and sardines.

data.text: Following
data.author: Mike Booth

data.text: I freeze steaks, veggies, scrambled eggs, milk, and other things. You will get two to three days before any problems. Also use the meals in a package.I use a food vacuum packer to shrink the packaging.
data.author: Bob Kirby

data.text: Tortillas, refried beans, cheese, hot sauce for lunches and ride food. For hot food, ramen with some type Of meat
data.author: Stacey Nieder

data.text: Takeout from restaurants along the route for me! I usually ride past at least a few decent places every day on my routes. Packing multiple days of food gets very heavy and bulky for me.
data.author: Adam Pagenkopf

data.text: Tortillas can be used as part of breakfast, lunch, dinner, AND dessert. Nutella is worth the weight and space it takes up.
data.author: Armando Agustin Santana

data.text: I bought an inexpensive dehydrator and dehydrate leftover veggies and meat. I put a bullion cube, some dried veggies, rice and meat in a bag. I add water and cook until done. I also pack hard cheese and dried sausage or biltong.
data.author: Douglas Miner
